subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Al-Hallaj: Killed for Saying 'I Am the Truth'
description: A micro-lesson that makes Al-Hallaj: Killed for Saying 'I Am the Truth' usable.

hook.text: 'I am the Truth.' In Islam, Truth is a name of God. Al-Hallaj claimed identity with the divine and was executed for it.

buildup.text: Al-Hallaj was a 10th-century Sufi who preached openly about mystical union with God. His fame threatened authorities.

discovery.text: He was imprisoned for 11 years, then tortured and crucified in Baghdad. His crime: speaking openly about inner truth.

twist.text: Later Sufis honored him as a martyr of love. He said the truth too loudly. Mystics since have learned to speak in code.

climax.text: Al-Hallaj shows the cost of mysticism: when inner experience contradicts public doctrine, the mystic pays with life.

punchline.text: He said 'I am God' and was killed for it. Mystics learned: speak softly.

quiz.question: Why was al-Hallaj executed?
options: Publicly claiming mystical union with God, which authorities saw as blasphemy
